_header: Thou us hast shend through foul looking
Note: For a closely related text see 5849.
_description: Debate between the Heart and the Eye, in a Latin sermon for Corpus Christi by Franciscan Lawrence Bretoun — five couplets

CULIi38.First Lines:
þu vs hast schent þour þy fol lokygþu us hast
                    schent þourch þy fol rekyng…
CULIi38.Last Lines:
…Hy wol þat þe heye wepe for is fole lokyngAnd
                    þe herte soruwe for is fol þenchyng
CULIi38.Note:
Sermon is on ff. 66-71, titled, ‘Panem de celo prestitisti
                        eis’.
CULIi38.Editions:
Stemmler,  Theo. 
             “More English Texts from MS. Cambridge University Library
                Ii.III.8.” 
             Anglia
         93 (1975): 1-16: 6.

OxfMert248.First Lines:
þou vs ast shend þoru þi fol lokingbut þou vs
                    ast shent þouru þi fol preching…
OxfMert248.Last Lines:
…Ich wil þat þe eie wepe ful sore& þat
                    þe herte sorwe & synne nomore
OxfMert248.Editions:
Coxe,  Henry Octavius. 
             Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque
                oxoniensibus….
         Oxon: e Typographeo academico, 1852: 97.
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             “A Homiletic Debate between Heart and Eye.” 
             Modern Language Notes
         30 (1915): 197-8: 198.
Pfander,  Homer Garrison. 
             “The Popular Sermon of the Medieval Friar in England.” 
         Diss. New York University, 1937: 50-1.
